div.p: We propose a generalization of the Hukuhara difference. First, the case of compact convex sets is examined; then, the results are applied to generalize the Hukuhara difference of fuzzy numbers, using their compact and convex level-cuts. Finally, a similar approach is suggested to attempt a generalization of division for real intervals and fuzzy numbers. Applications to solving interval and fuzzy linear equations and fuzzy differential equations are shown.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: It is well known that in set-valued (e.g. interval) and in fuzzy arithmetic, the standard Minkowski addition and multiplication are not invertible operations and the idea of finding some inverse operation has been a field of long interest; a well known and largely used example is the Hukuhara difference, proposed in [20], but in many applications it appears to have several limitations and to be very restrictive.

On the other hand, inversion of addition and multiplication is fundamental in interval and fuzzy arithmetic and analysis, with applications to the solution of equations, to the concepts of differentiability, to interval and fuzzy integral and differential equations, to interval and fuzzy regression analysis, etc.

The study of interval and fuzzy equations has been considered for a long time, following various approaches; methods to solve fuzzy equations have been developed in connections with the techniques of interval and set-valued analysis (see e.g. [4,[6][7][8][9][10][11]19,22,31] and, for interval analysis, see [27,29]). Also systems of fuzzy equations have been considered e.g. in [28,30,36,40,32].

The interval and fuzzy differential equations (FDE) have a long history (see e.g. [23,1,34] for recent results and for other references) and the use of the classical Hukuhara derivative in FDE has been criticized (see e.g. [21,[14][15][16][17]2]).
A generalization of Hukuhara difference, as the least squares or L 2 -norm solution of equation A + X = B, has been proposed in [13] and used in [18] in the context of fuzzy linear regression.
In this paper we propose generalizations of difference and division as inverse operations (in some sense) to addition and multiplication.

For the difference, we consider the general setting of set-valued arithmetic and we suggest some generalizations (the classical Hukuhara difference is a special case) for compact sets, for compact convex sets (in particular compact intervals) and for fuzzy sets with compact and convex -cuts (in particular fuzzy numbers).
For the division, we consider the setting of interval-valued arithmetic and of fuzzy numbers. Both operations are related to two important problems in the interval and fuzzy arithmetic and analysis:

(a) the solution of linear equations and (b) the (generalized) differentiability of interval-and fuzzy-valued functions and the use of the corresponding derivative in the formulation of interval and fuzzy differential equations.

The two topics have been addressed by a consistent scientific activity and numerous papers appeared in the literature. It is out of the scope of this paper to discuss both problems in detail; but we will remark how the proposed generalizations can be useful for both problems.

The paper is organized as follows. Section 2 introduces the generalizations of the Hukuhara difference for compact and compact convex sets. The important cases of compact intervals and multidimensional boxes are detailed in Section 3. Section 4 introduces the generalized Hukuhara difference (gH-difference) for fuzzy numbers and gives conditions for its existence. Section 5 considers a generalization of interval and fuzzy division. Possible applications to linear equations and fuzzy differentiability are briefly illustrated in Section 6.

div.head: Applications of gH-difference and g-division
div.p: Two important applications of the generalized difference and division are in the field of fuzzy linear equations and fuzzy derivative.

Solving a interval or a fuzzy linear equation AX + B = C has been addressed by various authors and the recent literature has concentrated on different approaches; essentially, the problem cannot be solved from a strict algebraic point of view as it is well known that in general no X (interval or fuzzy number) exists such that equality AX + B = C is satisfied. For example, the solution based on the application of the extension principle (i.e. X = {x|ax + b = c for a ∈ A, b ∈ B and c ∈ C}) will not satisfy the equation algebraically.
For the fuzzy case, some authors (see [11]) have proposed a procedure where the possible solutions are ordered by preference, like:

1. try to find the interval-arithmetic-based solution X 1 (using the -cuts) satisfying exactly our equation; if such a solution exists (i.e. the resulting -cuts produce a fuzzy number) then accept it; 2. otherwise, apply the extension principle or, depending on the problem at hand, 3. apply approximated interval arithmetic.
In the first subsection, we show that the proposed generalized difference and division can be used to produce a solution of interval and algebraic equations.

The second subsection addresses the definition of the derivative for interval-valued and fuzzy-valued functions and its application to interval and fuzzy differential equations. Also this problem has received great attention in the recent literature. Using the gH-difference proposed in this paper, in [34] the advantages of this new definition are illustrated for the interval case and it seems to be a useful tool to overcome several difficulties posed by the standard Hukuhara derivative, e.g. its restricted range of existence and the possibilistic irreversibility effect described e.g. in [13,17].

A recent study in collaboration with B. Bede (see [34]) has presented a new approach to model interval uncertainty in dynamical systems and interval differential equations, related but more general than the differential inclusion model (see [21,23]). In particular, the derivative of an interval-valued function, based on the new gH-difference, allows the possibility of solutions without restrictions imposed by the clssical Hukuhara derivative, i.e. the increasing uncertainty effect. See [14][15][16][17] for a critic of the use of classical Hukuhara derivative in fuzzy differential equations; see also [2] for an extended approach to fuzzy differential equations.

div.head: Conclusions and further research
div.p: In this paper, we analyze the possibility of generalizing the Hukuhara difference for compact and convex compact sets, including the special case of unidimensional and multidimensional intervals (boxes). We suggest a definition of the difference operation 0 g , called gH-difference, which extends the well-known Hukuhara difference, and we characterize its existence (for compact convex sets) in terms of support functions. The proposed gH-difference always exists in the one-dimensional interval case and a simple necessary and sufficient condition for its existence in the multidimensional interval case is given. The gH-difference is also suggested for fuzzy numbers and we give simple conditions for its existence and the rules to determine it.

We adopt a similar approach to define a generalization of division ÷ g , called g-division, of unidimensional intervals (for which it always exists) and for fuzzy numbers and we show properties and existence conditions.

Work in progress uses the proposed gH-difference operator to define generalized differentiability for interval-and fuzzy-valued functions and for theory and numerical algorithms in interval and fuzzy differential equations (see [34] for the interval case and [33] for fuzzy differential equations).
